content:
Posted: August 19, 2013
												Autism is a disorder of neural development characterized by impaired social interaction and verbal and non-verbal communication, and by restricted, repetitive or stereotyped behavior. The diagnostic criteria require that symptoms become apparent before a child is three years old.[2] Autism affects information processing in the brain by altering how nerve cells and their synapses connect and organize; how this occurs is not well understood.[3] It is one of three recognized disorders in the autism spectrum (ASDs), the other two being Asperger syndrome, which lacks delays in cognitive development and language, and pervasive developmental disorder, not otherwise specified (commonly abbreviated as PDD-NOS), which is diagnosed when the full set of criteria for autism or Asperger syndrome are not met.[4] Autism has a strong genetic basis, although the genetics of autism are complex and it is unclear whether ASD is explained more by rare mutations, or by rare combinations of common genetic variants.[5] In rare cases, autism is strongly associated with agents that cause birth defects.[6] Controversies surround other proposed environmental causes, such as heavy metals, pesticides or childhood vaccines;[7] the vaccine hypotheses are biologically implausible and lack convincing scientific evidence.[8] The prevalence of autism is about 1–2 per 1,000 people worldwide, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) report 20 per 1,000 children in the United States are diagnosed with ASD as of 2012 (up from 11 per 1,000 in 2008).[7][9][10] The number of people diagnosed with autism has been increasing dramatically since the 1980s, partly due to changes in diagnostic practice and government-subsidized financial incentives for named diagnoses;[10] the question of whether actual prevalence has increased is unresolved.[11] Parents usually notice signs in the first two years of their child's life.[12] The signs usually develop gradually, but some autistic children first develop more normally and then regress.[13] Early behavioral, cognitive, or speech interventions can help autistic children gain self-care, social, and communication skills.[12] Although there is no known cure,[12] there have been reported cases of children who recovered.[14] Not many children with autism live independently after reaching adulthood, though some become successful.[15] An autistic culture has developed, with some individuals seeking a cure and others believing autism should be accepted as a difference and not treated as a disorder.[16]

												A beautifully made game that is amazing in almost every way. Aside from the fact that you can't save, it is still absolutely wonderful! The graphics, design, randomness of the items and location, and the way it increasingly gets difficult. The Binding of Issac pulls you in. It is like an addiction that cannot be satisfied until the game is beaten, and the way that you cannot save just fuels the addiction more to beat the game. Game over.Time to restart... Again.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												A really fun game.  You play as a young child who constantly gets bullied by his mother.  He is ridiculed at school and everyone around him defecates on him.  The goal of this game is to progress through floors of your basement in order to kill your mum - the big poo monster.  It is fun to just chill in your house and play.  There is a wide range of items to collect in the game which help you on a run such as trinkets or cards.  There are also 5 characters other than Isaac which are unlocked via various methods.  Overall I would give this an 8.5/10.  The music and visuals are brilliant.  The levels are randomly generated to some extent.  The one downside to me would be that it gets repetitive but the range of characters can make up for it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
For more reviews and gameplay videos by Morgoth, check out the profile or the Twitch channel at twitch.tv/morgoth0221I'm not sure I can accurately describe how much I respect this game.  And alright, I'll say it, I LOVE this game.  Or to be more accurate, I am ADDICTED to this game.  I want to say I hate it's brutal unforgiving difficulty (especially after you hit the last treasure room and you get the poop or some equally useless item and yes there are more useless items than the poop), but in all reality, it is it's randomness and roguelike nature that made me fall in love with it.  The enemies are incredibly varied for a game style that is so simplistic and yet beautiful.  The story, captivating to the point that it has spawned HUNDREDS of theories on what the hell is really going on in Isaac's nightmarish world.  This is truly a once in a lifetime type of game in how magnificent it is and how well it keeps dragging you back in until you've beaten EVERYTHING.  You beat Mom?  Good job!  But did you really kill her?You beat her heart?  Awesome!  But how many times did you kill it?  Not enough...You beat It Lives??  Wow, you're really dedicated!  But Satan is still laughing at you...Satan has been brought down???  Time for a real challenge in yourself...You killed yourself????  Incredible!!  But the real last boss is still crying in his chest...Of course the main reason I keep coming back are the items.  THE ITEMS!!!  The activated items, the trinkets, the bombs, the tarot cards, every item is unique and forces you to play with a certain strategy.  Yes there are "crap" items, but if there is one thing I've learned, it is to never give up on a run.  I learned that one by obtaining the incredible combo of Polyphemus and Brimstone.  And you never know what you're going to stumble upon in Isaac's world.I've put 70 hours into Fallout 3, 45 into Dark Souls, and 70+ hours into Binding of Isaac.  I'm not saying it's a better game than either of those, but those numbers should speak for themselves.  Score: 9.5/10 (damn poop)

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
The Binding of Isaac. A flash semi-bullet hell satirical game on Christianity.The story goes that you are a young child named Isaac whom is stripped of fun and enjoyment in simple life after Mother has heard the voice of God demand that all things sin is removed. Hearing His one last wish from the high heavens, Mother grabs a knife and traps Isaac in his room, his only escape being a trapdoor leading below the foundation of the house. One powerful bash through the door and down goes the poor child.The objective of the game is the clear any rooms you enter of monstrosities that lie in your way as you travel deeper and deeper in the depths of your own basement, or maybe a cellar; crawling around the caves and catacombs, throughout the Depths of Nercopolis; and facing the one they call... Mom! Along the way, you find pick-ups, items, tarot cards, and pills that could do good or could do harm to Isaac as you take him on a somewhat sad (but fun!) venture to escape.ReviewThe GoodThough I had originally thought this game was kinda sad, I eventually got it, played it, and actually found myself excited over playing it over and over, unlocking a variety of cool items and using sweet powers. Aside from Isaac, you can also play other characters that have different starter abilites (ex. Magdalene, Cain, Eve), each unlocking a new item with every successful playthrough. If you add in the Wrath of the Lamb DLC, there are also challenges that start you out with preset powers and curses--another method of unlocking fantastic pick-ups.The BadIt is possible that anything kinda bad in this game were cleared up in the "sequel," Rebirth. (This portion of the review will be edited at a later time.)Concluding CommentsSeeing everyone (at one point) playing this game persuaded me to make an attempt to give it a go, and I do not at all regret making such a decision. The Binding of Isaac is an excellent action game that deserves the amount of support it has gotten. And Rebirth has done great justice. --Hermix.

Meanwhile, President James Marshall (Harrison Ford) is hiding after an attack on the ship where he must reunite with his family before they end up victims to Ivan's plan if the president doesn't release a Russian prisoner who happens to be a general and a terrorist.The film itself is a nail bitter thriller with an all star cast as Ford and Oldman play their usual good guy/villain roles with Glenn Close, Wendy Crewson, Xander Berkerly and William H. Macy in supporting roles. If there was such thing where Harrison Ford had a nomination for president, I would vote.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
Run, Fight, Die, Repeat!In a few words, this would be the game. It's a weird rogue like, quite addictive little game. It's one of the few games where getting an achievement actually helps in-game, the majority of them are unlocking new items, items that you might or might not need in your "dungeon" exploring. Filled with a variety of items, which give you new powers and new aesthetics as well, every time getting randomized, one gameplay in 100 isn't even nearly the same, despite having the same levels, the maps and items are always random, but you could slowly but surly start figuring out some patterns, despite having a minimalistic tutorial at the start, you will be on your own after room 1. The whole game is a combination of LUCK and SKILL, both of them which are raised by EXPERIENCE (actually playing and replaying the game), it also involves some currency/item management and some though decisions, despite the lack of an actual inventory, you will gamble your way to the top or you will play it safe, the decision is yours.WARNING: The game uses flash, not just once it happened to me that the game would crash due to high number of powerups/items picked up during the gameplay, resulting to a laggy/crashy gameplay. I played it a while ago, I heard of an upcoming new version, not sure if they updated or fixed the current one.In rest, nothing bad that I could say about it, except that you will probably die a lot and it has good ambiental music.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												I'll be honest. When I first saw this game I thought that it was one of the most stupid things I had ever seen. The artstyle looked childish to me and I found that it didn't match the dark atmosphere of the rest of the game. The fact that the main character is constantly crying seemed absurd and the gameplay looked boring and unappealing.But daaaamn was I wrong.Once you get the hang of the game mechanics (which may take a few hours) you'll really get addicted to it. There is so much to find out, so many different enemies, so many secrets, so many items with so many different effects.Each run is truly unique and the combat has an unexpected depth to it so that you will get constantly better which is again very motivating and fun.The game is difficult (at the beginning at least) and it is a bit of luck involved but that just adds to the uniqueness of every run and makes it even more satisfying when you get good items and have good run.The soundtrack is also just glorious and fits the creepy atmosphere perfectly.And the artstyle...you'll learn to love it. It may look very peculiar at the beginning but with the sick character design and the soundtrack it creates a very morbid experience which pulls you in again and again.It's easily the best rogue-like game I've ever played and it may just be the best out there.If you are intrested I suggest just give it a try. It's cheap, so you can't go wrong. It really has a lot more to offer then it seems and chances are high that, despite the first impression, you will fall in love with it.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Binding of Isaac is a great example of a well-executed indie title that marries interestingly odd and obscure art and story references with engaging twitch-reflex  gameplay. It's essentially a twin-stick shooter with power ups set in an unique dungeon environment. It has numerous rogue-like elements as well. It's lacking resolutions higher than 720P, and when in Windowed mode it plays in a 4:3 square that looks fairly small on a 1080 screen. While in fullscreen mode, you cannot access the Steam overlay. Other than few minor gripes listed above, this is a fun little rogue-like twin-stick-style adventure shooter set in a level-by-level dungeon design.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												I bought this game for 1$ and was quite amazed about how interesting it was. Basically, you play Isaac and have to defeat ennemies and bosses in various rooms. You kill ennemies by shooting them with your tears or by "bombing" them. This game is a "rogue-like" : you go through doors, not knowing what you'll get, and have to find the bosses in the various different floors, along with the "item-rooms" that level-up your tears or give you new abilities.The whole game is RNG, every floor is always randomly generated and this is the main point of the game : no playthrough will be identical, ever, and that's what offers a great replay value.Another important thing : permadeath. If you die in this game, you have to start back at the beginning  (with another layout of course, since everything is RNG), and trust me, you'll die often. But each time you die, you learn from your mistakes and make better the next time. At the beginning, you'll be happy if you reach level 5, but at the end, reaching level 8 is quite normal. (Note : if you unlock new item, death doesn't affect that)[Pros] : + RNG all around the place = infinite replay value+ 2 minutes to get the point of the game and the controlls, 200 hours to fully master it+ A ton of items and stuff, you will learn something new at each playthrough and get better and better+ Items have synergies and can be "combined" for powerful results+ Awesome price for awesome game (under 1$ in sale)+ Will train your reflexes, strategy and learning abilities + Cool graphic style+ You can make it work smoothly even on a potato computer+ Simple controls : WASD to move, Arrows to Shoot, E to Bomb, Space to Use Item, Q to use Pill/Card ; that's all.+ A ton of "secrets" to master to get better+ "Humoristic" items with Internet Memes References (Lemon, Hoop de Loop, Forever Alone, Super Meat Boy...)[Cons] : - Hard at the beginning, can be very frustrating if you don't like the "learn by mistakes" approach (=/= die and retry)- The game engine can lag sometimes, the game isn't fully oprimized- Don't hope beating the "last" boss with under 60 hours of /played (but the game is fun even if you never finish it)- RNG land, sometimes, you'll get f*** up hard by bad RNG[Conslusion] : Anyone that is ok with games that involve reflexes should try this, at least if it's in sale for less than 1 buck. 10/10

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												note: I played this mostly offline, and have put considerably more than 4 hours into it.I know it's not a popular opinion, but I really don't like the Binding of Isaac. There are a lot of things to like about it, most notably the wonderfully grotesque design, but I personally hate the core mechanics. I really really tried to love it (largely because it was a game that was easy to play on the bus), but eventually gave up.Ok, so Binding of Isaac is a rogue-like, so we already know you're going to be dying and restarting a lot. That doesn't bother me. What does bother me is that you don't get better with each subsequent death. There's no lineage system or inventory hold over that helps you make a little more progress with each new game, you are just literally starting from scratch each time. And the controls are not complicated, so there isn't even an element of mastering the game's mechanics as progression.And then there's other major design decision that I hate, the complete randomness. Procedurally generated games can be a ton of fun and help to keep things interesting, but your success in each run of this game is largely decided before you even leave the first room. The enemies being random is great, it keeps things from being rote. However, the power-ups being random is a huge problem because of the disparity between them. Power-ups can be utterly worthless, or god-tier, and you never know what you're going to go get. But because your previous attempts don't have any impact, you're relying entirely on the much necessary power-ups, which are sometimes just going to be useless.One of my best runs was actually one of my first. In one of the first rooms I picked up a power-up that just devastated every enemy I came across. I've never been that lucky again. I enjoy challenging games, but there needs to be some sort of progression either through leveling or mastery of the mechanics, and Binding of Isaac has neither. There are of course going to be minor improvements to how you play, but for the most part, your 100th attempt has just as much chance of success as your 2nd attempt, and it's going to be based on what procedural roll you got. While this clearly doesn't deter most people, I find it to be an uninteresting set of mechanics that generally lead to wasting time on a run that was doomed to fail.

Posted: April 15, 2013
												An absolutely amazing and extremely addictive roguelike that will leave you wanting more and more and more. At least 100 hours in and I can never get enough this is by far one of the best values you can get for your money on this site.-GraphicsNothing mind blowing to see here, keep in mind this is an indie title, but the visuals are very sharp and crisp and the hand drawn style is something I think everyone could appreciate. Ed Mcmillen brings his dark imagination alive with cute enemy design with dark tones in a vivid and smooth way. 9/10-SoundAnother excellent aspect of this game, Danny Baranowsky graces this game with an intoxicating score that never gets old and is always welcomed. The sound effects also nail it with gross tones and excellent notes that bring more life into the game. 10/10-ControlsOne of the few areas I believed needed work. A game that is a pain to play with mouse and keyboard, but feels amazing with controller, just needs mapping attention. I feel like this game deserved some native controller support. Once you get the controller mapped and configured however, it feels like a dream, I highly recommend using an Xbox controller when mapping. 7/10-GameplayA randomly generated dungeon crawler, you'll complete a set number of levels and floors all ending with a boss fight. The level structure for this game as well as item placement and boss encounters are all random, which the only strategy for this game has to come from experience which is completely amazing. You clear rooms, discover treasure, acquire upgrades, fight bosses in the end. Will you make it? Will you get all the way to the end and choke? That's up to you. This is definitely the shining tower in this title which is most important in any game. 10/10-Replayability I believe I already used the term "Random" so I really cant stress enough just how impressive and addictive this title is. Everything about this game is random, item placement, loadout possibility, the structure and all is a random dip. 11/10Overall while no game is perfect, this game comes pretty damn close. 9/10. Buy it if you don't have it, there are no regrets here.

Posted: January 31, 2014
												As someone who has not put a great amount of hours into the game, my review comes with some understandable questioning. However, I still feel as though I have a good feel of the game already, going through many different playthroughs until I finally reached the point where I had the power to beat the final boss and the second final boss in the second playthrough. With that in mind, I find myself going through spurts of loving this game to pieces, playing it bit by bit and getting better as time goes by, collecting more and more items as my personal list of achievements grows. With that in mind, The Binding of Issac more than delivers on its content for the price of 5 dollars (plus seven if you get the incredibly fun "Wrath of the Lamb" DLC). The game runs as an overhead shooter that drops you in the middle of a basement of horrors, pitting you against enemy after enemy as you struggle to survive against the different waves. At its very core the game is very simple: Kill the enemies with your weapon of choice while also avoiding the enemies with WASD at the same time. Once you are able to grasp the difficulty, it makes this game a very rewarding experience. But the true gold of the game shines through as you realize that there is a great deal of items available. In fact, there are so many items available that it makes for a different experience every time you play the game. Add the randomly generated dungeons and enemies throughout the game and you get to the point where you find yourself with an entirely different experience each time you play through the game. That being said, the game is not for those who are easily frustrated, as you will find yourself playing through it multiple times before you even get close to your desired goal. Despite that fact, I find the game well worth the seven dollars it is sold for.

Posted: February 26, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac is one of my favorite games that I never expected to like at all.  With its brown and gray levels, pictures of a lo-fi crying naked kid on the splash screen, I wasn't sure what to think at first.  When I first bought the game during a sale, I played it a few times, died, and shut down the game.  I didn't get it at all.  Then, a few months later, I tried again.  I found a better way to use the controls (I used a mouse and keyboard, instead of just the keyboard) and I picked up the item My Little Unicorn.  I was hooked.  I died milions of times.  I wanted to see what other messed up items the game held - Mom's bra?  Demon lasers?  The best part was that the items changed the appearance of your character.  Every playthrough was different.  I unlocked other characters.  I struggled to fight Mom.  When I finally defeated Mom I cheered aloud.  I hadn't felt such exuberance over a boss fight since early raiding in World of Warcraft.Who shouldn't play this game?  Christian literalists with no sense of humor... otherwise, I highly recommend it to anyone else.

Posted: October 2, 2011
												"So if I die I start over?""yes. you start over with nothing.""You star over with knowledge."Binding o' Isaac is an action-arcade game, or 2D Zelda games mashed with random elements and perma-death. Crawling through your dungeon basement, you fight minion and boss abominations with your tears, while collecting stuff. You know, classic kid adventures.You will not win on your first game. The controls are odd and frustrating at first, but can be learned. And half the fun is doing it again, applying what you learned and having it pay off (and getting different loot!) Fighting itself is as fun as LttP (read: it gets the job done.)And everything is tongue-in-cheek dark. Made by half of Meat Boy's team, Ed says the story was based off some old christian VHS tapes he found. And upgrades are things like Isaac's puppy's head, which brings back the trauma and causes more tears.$5 (or $6, and get the ost, which is great.) Tons to unlock (characters, new items appear, cutscenes), Bible lore spin, and pretty fun. Check it.

												Easily one of my favourite games, and it shows, I have like 400 hours clocked on it. It's a glorious, disturbing, bloody, frustrating mess of wonderful gameplay (if not with a few bugs, in both sense of the word), twisted visuals, and a scryptic, vague story just enough to create mass speculation on metaphor and representation. If you're reading this far, you've spent too much time NOT playing The Binding of Isaac

Posted: November 28, 2013
												Sort of a game where you don't have to think about the story to play it, but has a pretty interesting plot if you do. Which can be pretty disturbing. Between the religious and pop culture references, there is a pretty dark story that might be about parental abandonment, abuse, and/or a child's overactive imagination.The graphics are simple and not too detailed, but even with such cartoony proportions, you might get some... peculiar upgrades to your character that might just cause your stomach to do a frontflip.It's a bit of a dungeon roguelike game, a bit of a bullet hell game -- specially in later levels where there's more enemies on the screen. You need good reflexes and a bit of strategy when it comes to choosing which items to keep and which to leave behind when you're on your way down the basement. A very good time killer, you're encouraged to play it to the end in one sitting, since, well, you lose all your progress when you die.If you can stand the gory, gross imagery you might come by in this game, it's definitely one I recommend playing.

Posted: September 16, 2014
												Caution: This game is really hard! The game has an expansion pack called "Wrath of the Lamb" wich I higly sugest getting. It is also the version I'm going to talk about.(If you're reading this after 4/11 you should go get rebirth instead)To beat the entire game, you have to get the "Platinum God" achievement. To get get this, you must unlock everything and complete the game 200 times. Yes. 200 times. Beating the game takes around 45 minutes so you can calculate for yourself how much you have to play to win.  I've played this game a lot, and I'm nearing completion. But let me tell you. When you finally get that Platinum God in your achievemnt showcase on your profile it will be amazing. Except that noone knows how hard it is so they won't be impressed.9/10 Has some minor flaws that can easily be forgotten when playing this endurance test of a game.Conclusion: Rub money on your screen untill it accepts your purchase.

Posted: July 29, 2012
												The Binding of Isaac is a game where your mother is corrupted by sin and tries to kill you to please her "lord" and just before death you escape into a mysterious cave hidden under your rug. Within said cave you must acquire upgrades and kill ugly, vile, and probably smelly enemies such as flies, zombie headless things... And not to forget bosses. Some bosses include but are not limited to: Monstro, Larry Jr., Chub, and last but not least...*drum roll* Steven! As you make your way to the final floor you must kill your mother with all the items you've acquired. (By the way the whole game revolves around killing your mother for the most part.).Once your mother is dead you must delve into her "womb" and make your way to her heart. To wrap things up, this game is pretty Bad... BADASS! The game can provide you with endless hours of gameplay, so try it out, I mean really, it's only $5.

												This game was made by Edmund McMuffinMan, the same guy who made Super Meat Boy so I picked it up one day when it was on sale. I mainly got it because it was recommended and it had trading cards so I didn't give it a fair chance when i first played it. A few months later I heard about Rebirth so I thought hmm, maybe I should give that game another chance... a real chance. So I did and now I love it! Posted: June 25, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac, and its DLC Wrath of the Lamb is an old school dungeon crawl, reminiscent of Legend of Zelda, and your worst nightmares and or mindscrews. I HIGHLY recommend it.to make it clear: this game takes the concept of grimdark and elopes with it. you might want a strong drink once you're done crying from its crippling difficulty, but just as with an abusive relationship, you can't help but come back to it for another helping. definitely a great game, with the simplicity you want in the controls, the difficulty you crave, unique graphics, and a soundtrack that will chill you right down your spine.have a listen here, this guy fell in love with the OST, while i go back to playing it.

Posted: June 13, 2014

Posted: December 31, 2013
												The Binding of Isaac has all you expect from a rogue-like: permadeath, randomized levels and items, tons of secrets and achievements to discover, unlockables...What did it for me is the ambiance. The story is minimal but still original, and is served well by a gorgeous soundtrack, simple yet nice looking graphics, and surprises like the arcade, the secret rooms, and so on.A downside of the game, for me, is the utter randomness of it. Sometimes you'll get lucky and have a super build, sometimes you'll just get crappy items over crappy items. I should warn you about it's difficulty, too. Some rooms are very hard and you need extra quick reaction time not to get hurt, and this is where Flash was a bad choice, making the game laggy when too many elements are on screen.Overall, it's still an awesome game that I recommended to lots of my friends, and some of them are even more hooked than me.

Posted: December 31, 2011
												This game is stylish, dark, mean, and *hard*. The good kind of hard, where your skill and practice *pay off*. Expect to die, a lot, but keep at it--some day, you'll rise to the occasion, and the Depths that were once a nightmare you couldn't imagine getting through alive will be just another level, even while the game's difficulty level gradually increases as you complete in-game challenges and stronger enemies start showing up earlier and earlier. Not to mention the long, long list of little accomplishments that will unlock some new plaything for future dungeons. This is easily one of the best uses for a five-spot (or less, some days--seriously, I've bought sodas more expensive than what this game will cost you during a good sale) you will ever find.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												I've had my fair share of The Binding of Isaac and what I can say for certain is that this easily falls in my favourite games list. At first when you get into the game nothing really makes much sense, items, goals, levels, story - it's all pretty confusing. But after 2-3 hours of playing and after a bit (20-ish) restarts you'll see that everything is well executed with infinte replayability in mind. Items are the most helpful and most weird aspect of the game, maybe the only thing that can compare to their weirdness is the story. Every item has its own effect on Isaac's stats and his visual appearance. I can guarantee that at the end Isaac will never look human. Items are randomly generated, like the levels, and add tons of variety and make sure that every run you do you'll get a different experience. The story is something that most people will probably ignore, or will not notice at all, but it is there. The end game cutscenes are the key component and after a few replays you'll get what it's all about and will probably want to find out more, to which I say that you should pick up the DLC for the game. It finishes the story and fills in some missing parts.The DLC is awesome, since it adds even more variety to the game, but be warned that if you're new to The Binding of Isaac and if you haven't put in a bit over 10 hours don't buy it just yet, because it makes the game a lot harder and might leave you struggling at the starting floors again. But aside from that all the new items and the new trinket system involved really help the game feel even more genuine and diverse.In conclusion, I'd just like to state again that the game is awesome and well worth the money. It's a good option to have when you want a fun and new experience and only have an hour to spare. When you get into the game it's gonna be hard to put it down. So why wait, start your experience now!

Posted: July 14, 2014
												Isaac comes to in the upper level of the basement and you, the player, must guide him through the dangers that lurk below. The UI is very similar to what you’d expect from an early Zelda title. You have three heart containers. Three counters keep track of your amount of coins, bombs, and keys. The dungeon layout is shown on the upper left and your current items are listed next to your heart containers. You start out with only your tears to fight off the grotesque creatures of the basement. Each floor of the basement is littered with a slew of enemies, chests, items, a treasure room, and a boss room. Upon entering a room, all of the doors will lock until every enemy in it has been defeated. You can blow open a door, but it will cost a single bomb. Useable items can often be found in chests, but are also dropped from enemies. These could be tarot cards, pills, or some other miscellaneous item. Where as the tarot cards have a specific use, pills have random uses. These range from incredibly useful to potentially harmful, so consume them at your own risk. Treasure rooms are marked by their gold outlines, and within them lies a single power-up. These power-ups can increase your speed, change your projectile type, increase your max HP, etc. Some power-ups are weak and their effects can leave more to be desired, while others can be complete game changers and turn the tide of battles in your favor. They’re creatively designed and include some pretty outlandish things like a pair of high heels and even dog food. They also change your physical appearance, and seeing as they stack infinitely, this can result in some pretty hilarious or gruesome appearances. As you progress throughout the game, Isaac’s exterior begins to reflect the hell that is the basement. There are a plethora of bosses and they all battle in different ways. Defeating a boss will open a trapdoor to the next level, and between each floor of the basement a cutscene plays that shows Isaac having a nightmare, often of him being publicly embarrassed. The cutscenes, although oddly humorous, add little depth to Isaac’s character as it can be assumed that the events he worries over never actually took place, seeing as some are pretty over-the-top, such as one where he dreams he was being pooped on by a group of people. The final boss is no other than Isaac’s mother. And even after you’ve managed to beat her, your adventure still isn’t over. There still remains another set of levels and a whole mess of enemies, secrets, items, and power-ups to find.Through and through, The Binding of Isaac is a bonafide roguelike in every sense of the term. Every dungeon is randomly generated, resulting in no two runs feeling exactly the same. You’re given simple controls and absolutely no tutorial of any sort. Like any self-respecting roguelike, this is a game of trial and error, and it isn’t afraid to hand you your behind on a silver platter. The staggering amount of enemies will force you to adapt to any situation, and you’ll find yourself dying often before you’ve learned most of the enemies’ maneuvers. Bosses deal a lot of damage fast and some will even spawn smaller enemies around themselves. Even after you’ve learned the behavior of every enemy in the game, you’ll still find yourself dying quite often. Useable items and power-ups add variation to the gameplay and the tactics you’ll use in combat. With the unbelievable amount of depth found in the seemingly simple game, The Binding of Isaac produces an experience that becomes insanely addictive and rarely feels stale, even after dozens of hours of playtime.The Binding of Isaac’s visual presentation is something straight from the mind of a madman. Its art style is sleek, simple, and endearing. The various brown hues of the basement stand apart from each other, enhanced by the excellent shading, but they’re just pieces in a whole that create an immersive and beautiful environment. The story is primarily told through Isaac’s drawings. It’s all nice and cutesy, that is until you actually walk around and see the dreadful conditions of the basement. A myriad of deformed and bloody enemies stalk the rooms and each seem to spout blood like a fountain upon dying. There are these worm-like enemies that actually look somewhat adorable, until they charge at you with their fangs bared, trying to eat your face off. Piles of poop lay scattered on the ground. The changes that accompany the power-ups can be humorous, but others completely change the way Isaac looks, essentially turning him into one of the monsters that he faces. The fact that you aren’t alone suggests that you aren’t the first to face the wickedness of Isaac’s mother, and the possibility that the enemies could be related to him makes the adventure even more cringe worthy. In some dungeons you’ll find a room in which you can purchase items in exchange for coins. Each of these shops feature a hanging Isaac-lookalike, their faces twisted with expressions of despair. It’s an enthralling visual endeavor that shocks you from the start and carries out its dark themes with precise execution.The Binding of Isaac’s soundtrack aims to emphasize the same contrast brought about by the art style, and it manages to do so quite well. The music is slightly upbeat and detracts from the hopelessness that Isaac feels as he wanders through the basement. At times the music speeds up just a bit and the volume increases, ramping up your adrenaline at the same time. There is a slight feeling of loneliness in the unknown created by the soundtrack, and this is where it slightly fractures the contrast and actually melds with the setting. Enemy and projectile sounds are squishy in nature, but impactful overall. The contrast between the game’s dark themes and relatively uplifting music is genuinely interesting and adds another layer of depth.Despite its numerous references and tie-ins to other forms of media, The Binding of Isaac does plenty to set itself apart from the pack. There are some really laughable moments in the otherwise grim depths of the basement: there’s a certain enemy that will scurry away from you, whimpering as it tries desperately to flee; of the hanging Isaac-lookalikes in the shops, one of them has a huge grin on his face; some of the items and power-ups are just meant to make you burst out laughing, like Mom’s Pad – a useable item that makes all enemies in a room retreat for several seconds. Also, it raises some very serious questions that most games wouldn’t dare ask. It ventures into often-untraveled territory by challenging our understanding of organized religion, mental illness, and child abuse. These are very touchy subjects and it’s admirable to see developers who aren’t afraid to speak on them. The Binding of Isaac proves to be a unique and addictive adventure. Its humor is welcoming and its roguelike nature results in an unbelievable amount of replay value. While it may look simple at first, there is a surprising amount of depth to be found. Its endearing art style and aesthetically pleasing soundtrack is welcoming, while its dark themes are perfectly executed in the story and character designs. More than just a fun game, it questions what we as a society perceive to be norms and challenges us to think differently. The only real downsides to the game are the lack of characterization on Isaac and the slight capitalization on nostalgia. Aside from that, it’s an incredible game that should be played by anyone who enjoys a solid roguelike – or just a good game in general – because it stands head and shoulders above its competition in the genre.

												The Binding of Isaac is a great game to spend a few minutes or even hours playing.The game is about a boy who's mom is overly religious When God asks her to lock her son away andtake all his things away, even clothes, she is more than happy to do as instructed. God then says Isaacis still "corrupted" and tells Mom to kill Isaac, which she goes to do without a second thought. Isaac, in desperation searches his room for a way out and finds a trap door under a rug which he flings open andjumps in just as Mom lunges into Isacc's room with a knife.In the basement is where the game takes place. Isaac has to fight through countless monsters with onlyhis tears. The goal is to get out of the basement but that is where all of the monsters come in makingIsaac's world a living hell, by cornering him and killing him.The game is permadeath and is really quite fun and challenging.  There are plenty of items to enhance Isaac's powers. One can make a deal with the devil or meet Crampus himself.

Posted: March 27, 2013
												A twinstick shooter/roguelike hybrid, The Binding Of Isaac combines a tough but mostly fair difficulty with near-infinite replay value. Each playthrough lasts only an hour or two (assuming you don't die early on), but the procedurally generated levels, enemies, and item spawns make each one unique. The sheer amount of content is also impressive: I've sunk over 115 hours into the game as of this writing, and there's still a good bit more I haven't unlocked or discovered yet.TBOI has an old school mindset to it, in that there are tons of different enemies and powerups, but the game does not spell out for you the best way to take on the enemies or make use of the powers, or sometimes even what the powers do. This might sound off-putting, but I find it provides for a highly satisfying sensation of skill progression as you work these things out for yourself. Over time, you will even begin making tactical decisions about when to skip a powerup that doesn't work well with your current build.The Wrath Of The Lamb DLC is also heartily recommended, which provides a huge increase to the number of powerups in the game, a new character to unlock, and an entirely new class of pickup, all of which make for even more build possibilities; special challenges that unlock new powerups upon completion; a plethora of new enemies, bosses, and level permutations; and even a brand new level at the endgame.In the interest of full disclosure, the game does have a number of bugs and glitches, including a rather annoying bug regarding unlocks that can result in 4 specific ones being removed from your save history, making you have to unlock them all over again. Very few of these bugs are gamebreaking though, and the few that do cause you to have to cancel your current playthrough are extremely rare (I've never encountered one in all my playtime). Reading the wiki page on bugs, and keeping a spare copy of your most recent so.sol file (which records your unlocks and settings), will help you avoid nearly all of them, and those that can't be avoided tend to be completely trivial at worst, so I would strongly advise you to not let these few minor annoyances dissuade you from picking up one of the best values for the money you can possibly find on Steam.

Posted: July 14, 2014
												Isaac comes to in the upper level of the basement and you, the player, must guide him through the dangers that lurk below. The UI is very similar to what you’d expect from an early Zelda title. You have three heart containers. Three counters keep track of your amount of coins, bombs, and keys. The dungeon layout is shown on the upper left and your current items are listed next to your heart containers. You start out with only your tears to fight off the grotesque creatures of the basement. Each floor of the basement is littered with a slew of enemies, chests, items, a treasure room, and a boss room. Upon entering a room, all of the doors will lock until every enemy in it has been defeated. You can blow open a door, but it will cost a single bomb. Useable items can often be found in chests, but are also dropped from enemies. These could be tarot cards, pills, or some other miscellaneous item. Where as the tarot cards have a specific use, pills have random uses. These range from incredibly useful to potentially harmful, so consume them at your own risk. Treasure rooms are marked by their gold outlines, and within them lies a single power-up. These power-ups can increase your speed, change your projectile type, increase your max HP, etc. Some power-ups are weak and their effects can leave more to be desired, while others can be complete game changers and turn the tide of battles in your favor. They’re creatively designed and include some pretty outlandish things like a pair of high heels and even dog food. They also change your physical appearance, and seeing as they stack infinitely, this can result in some pretty hilarious or gruesome appearances. As you progress throughout the game, Isaac’s exterior begins to reflect the hell that is the basement. There are a plethora of bosses and they all battle in different ways. Defeating a boss will open a trapdoor to the next level, and between each floor of the basement a cutscene plays that shows Isaac having a nightmare, often of him being publicly embarrassed. The cutscenes, although oddly humorous, add little depth to Isaac’s character as it can be assumed that the events he worries over never actually took place, seeing as some are pretty over-the-top, such as one where he dreams he was being pooped on by a group of people. The final boss is no other than Isaac’s mother. And even after you’ve managed to beat her, your adventure still isn’t over. There still remains another set of levels and a whole mess of enemies, secrets, items, and power-ups to find.Through and through, The Binding of Isaac is a bonafide roguelike in every sense of the term. Every dungeon is randomly generated, resulting in no two runs feeling exactly the same. You’re given simple controls and absolutely no tutorial of any sort. Like any self-respecting roguelike, this is a game of trial and error, and it isn’t afraid to hand you your behind on a silver platter. The staggering amount of enemies will force you to adapt to any situation, and you’ll find yourself dying often before you’ve learned most of the enemies’ maneuvers. Bosses deal a lot of damage fast and some will even spawn smaller enemies around themselves. Even after you’ve learned the behavior of every enemy in the game, you’ll still find yourself dying quite often. Useable items and power-ups add variation to the gameplay and the tactics you’ll use in combat. With the unbelievable amount of depth found in the seemingly simple game, The Binding of Isaac produces an experience that becomes insanely addictive and rarely feels stale, even after dozens of hours of playtime.The Binding of Isaac’s visual presentation is something straight from the mind of a madman. Its art style is sleek, simple, and endearing. The various brown hues of the basement stand apart from each other, enhanced by the excellent shading, but they’re just pieces in a whole that create an immersive and beautiful environment. The story is primarily told through Isaac’s drawings. It’s all nice and cutesy, that is until you actually walk around and see the dreadful conditions of the basement. A myriad of deformed and bloody enemies stalk the rooms and each seem to spout blood like a fountain upon dying. There are these worm-like enemies that actually look somewhat adorable, until they charge at you with their fangs bared, trying to eat your face off. Piles of poop lay scattered on the ground. The changes that accompany the power-ups can be humorous, but others completely change the way Isaac looks, essentially turning him into one of the monsters that he faces. The fact that you aren’t alone suggests that you aren’t the first to face the wickedness of Isaac’s mother, and the possibility that the enemies could be related to him makes the adventure even more cringe worthy. In some dungeons you’ll find a room in which you can purchase items in exchange for coins. Each of these shops feature a hanging Isaac-lookalike, their faces twisted with expressions of despair. It’s an enthralling visual endeavor that shocks you from the start and carries out its dark themes with precise execution.The Binding of Isaac’s soundtrack aims to emphasize the same contrast brought about by the art style, and it manages to do so quite well. The music is slightly upbeat and detracts from the hopelessness that Isaac feels as he wanders through the basement. At times the music speeds up just a bit and the volume increases, ramping up your adrenaline at the same time. There is a slight feeling of loneliness in the unknown created by the soundtrack, and this is where it slightly fractures the contrast and actually melds with the setting. Enemy and projectile sounds are squishy in nature, but impactful overall. The contrast between the game’s dark themes and relatively uplifting music is genuinely interesting and adds another layer of depth.Despite its numerous references and tie-ins to other forms of media, The Binding of Isaac does plenty to set itself apart from the pack. There are some really laughable moments in the otherwise grim depths of the basement: there’s a certain enemy that will scurry away from you, whimpering as it tries desperately to flee; of the hanging Isaac-lookalikes in the shops, one of them has a huge grin on his face; some of the items and power-ups are just meant to make you burst out laughing, like Mom’s Pad – a useable item that makes all enemies in a room retreat for several seconds. Also, it raises some very serious questions that most games wouldn’t dare ask. It ventures into often-untraveled territory by challenging our understanding of organized religion, mental illness, and child abuse. These are very touchy subjects and it’s admirable to see developers who aren’t afraid to speak on them. The Binding of Isaac proves to be a unique and addictive adventure. Its humor is welcoming and its roguelike nature results in an unbelievable amount of replay value. While it may look simple at first, there is a surprising amount of depth to be found. Its endearing art style and aesthetically pleasing soundtrack is welcoming, while its dark themes are perfectly executed in the story and character designs. More than just a fun game, it questions what we as a society perceive to be norms and challenges us to think differently. The only real downsides to the game are the lack of characterization on Isaac and the slight capitalization on nostalgia. Aside from that, it’s an incredible game that should be played by anyone who enjoys a solid roguelike – or just a good game in general – because it stands head and shoulders above its competition in the genre.

Posted: August 2, 2014
												Take the original legend of zelda, a generous helping of heavy religious themes and overtones, internet culture and then throw political correctness out of the nearest window and put it all in a blender.  what you end up with is a truly great game where every single playthrough is completely random and unique from the items and powerups you find to the layout and enemies you find in each and every room you enter. half of the fun of isaac is never quite knowing what you're going to find or come across in that particular playthrough and finding new items and discovering what they do and how they combine with the other items you've discovered, the fact that your characters appearance also changes, sometimes drastically, depending on what you've found is another aspect that adds to the discovery of the game.in terms of negatives if you don't do well with bullet hell games then you will definitely find the later areas of the game challenging as it can be unforgiving, but rewarding, at times, also if you think you would take offence to the idea of a small child fighting off the corpses of his dead siblings with his own tears then you should probably give the game a miss lolbut overall i love the game, has become one of my favourites of all time and im just waiting for rebirth now.

Posted: October 3, 2014
												Isaac and his mother lived alone in a small house on a hill. Isaac kept to himself drawing pictures and playing with his toys as his mom watched Christian broadcasts on the television. Life was simple and they were both happy. That was until the day Isaac's mom heard a voice from above:"Your son has become corrupted by sin. He needs to be saved.""I will do my best to save him, my Lord," Isaac's mother replied, rushing into Isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life.Again the voice called to her:"Isaac's soul is still corrupt. He needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world and confess his sins.""I will follow your instructions, Lord. I have faith in thee," Isaac's mother replied as she locked Isaac in his room away from the evils of the world.One last time Isaac's mom heard the voice of God calling to her:"You've done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to me. To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you.""Yes, Lord. Anything," Isaac's mother begged."To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice. Your son, Isaac, will be this sacrifice. Go into his room and end his life as an offering to me, to prove you love me above all else.""Yes, Lord," she replied, grabbing a butchers knife from the kitchen.Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear. Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trapdoor to the basement hidden under his rug. Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch just as his mother burst through his door and threw himself down into the unknown depths below...

												This game has taken far too many hours out of my life to comfortably admit to my friends and family. Simple mechanics combined with a deep rogue-like style of gameplay make The Binding of Isaac an affordable, addicting, and sometimes disturbing must-have in any gamer's collection.

Posted: June 26, 2013
												Meet Isaac, a child raised by his mother.  One day she is told by God that her son has become corrupted and must be relieved of his earthly possessions.  God then tells her to she needs to kill her son, which Isaac doesn't think is a very good idea.  He then plunges himself down a trapdoor to escape his mothers lust to please her God.This Zelda-like dungeon crawler has virtually endless replayability.  Each time you begin, the game randomly generates floors for you to fight through to get to your mom, the main antagonist.  The variety continues as you unlock other characters to start out as, each having his/her own special attributes.  The Wrath of the Lamb DLC adds many new bosses and items.Gameplay on keyboard uses the wasd keys for movement and arrow keys for directional shooting by default.  On controller, it acts much the same, utilizing both analog sticks.  This game was made in flash and isn't very well optimized.  It lags often (and occasionally crashes), mostly dependent on how crazy the items you picked up are, which brings me to the item combinations.  There are many items in The Binding of Isaac that synergize with each other, adding to the uniqueness of each run.  There are also many unlockable playable characters.The game is played from a top-down perspective.  The floor is separated by rooms that are all the same size, but there is a ton of variety between them.  The aforementioned Wrath of the Lamb DLC adds many more rooms to discover and explore.  The sound effects in The Binding of Isaac would be unsettling for any new player, but it grows on you the more you play.  The soundtrack was constructed by Danny Baranowsky, who's work is also in Crypt of the NecroDancer.Although it has its flaws, it's an amazing roguelike  I'd recommend The Binding of Isaac to anyone looking to get the most out of their money.  Isaac has given me over 500 hours of gameplay, and I'll still feel like knocking out a run from time to time.  With the amount of characters, items, and rooms it's possible to encounter, no two runs through this game will ever be the same.Pros:*Great soundtrack*Many different enemies*Replayability*No two games are ever the sameCons:*Poorly optimized*Lags often*Crashes on occasion7/10

Posted: April 23, 2014
												This awesomely fun game is everything a roguelike should be:  quick and dirty, with lots of gross monsters and more items that help than hinder.  These items, by the way, often change up the gameplay in dramatic and surprising ways (example: you start off shooting teardrops at enemies, but you might suddenly find a devil head that lets you barf huge streams of blood across the screen).  It's like a cutely sacrilegious Zelda (NES) meets Robotron: The Cardinal Direction-only Edition.  Only negative that I have is that the game runs in Flash, and you have to run JoytoKey or some such to be able to use your gamepad.  And believe you me, the gamepad is a must.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												This is my first review so feedback on how I did would be appreciated. This was one of the first games I got on steam. Some friends told me that it was not worth its full price and I should just wait for the discount but I didnt listen to them. This game is completely worth its price. Its only five dollars without the DLC and eight dollars with the DLC making it extremely cheap. This game requires very little power so I could play it on my terrible laptop. When I first started playing this game I was so bad at it and I wondered how anyone could ever beat it. But if you play this game for the first few rounds you will start to want to play more and more and beat what you got last game. The first ten times you beat the game, even if its with the same character, you get something new. Then you can beat it with all the other characters. Every character has their good parts and bad parts. Character choice is also a crucial decision even in the late game making you really have to figure out who you like to pay as. Some poeple say that this game is very small and that is true but you have to remember that this actually started out as a flash game. ocne youve beat the game a lot it starts to feel a bit repetative but to give you an example of what I mean by a lot, I have played over 200 hours of this game and only in the past 2 hours or so did I start to feel it getting boring. But that means that I got about 25 hours of gameplay for every dollar I spent. This is a great game if you like roguelike games. Every run is either a bit or completely different from the others depending on what items you choose to pick up. This isnt a multiplayer game but its fun to play around friends to see peoples different strategys. I really enjoyed this game and all my friends hate me because I played to much of it. 9.5/10Stats:Money: 10/10 (Really cheap game)Controls: 10/10 (They work and they're easy to learn)Sound: 8/10 (The soundtrack is ok, I dont normally play with volume on)Replayability 10/10 (200 hours, each run is about a half an hour need I say more?)

Posted: September 19, 2014
 "Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, (...) and threw himself down into the unknown depths below." A kind of game that I(and probably a lot of other gamers) really like- a game where it has great gameplay, combined with deep and great story.The entire story is a satire about a bible story The Binding of Issac, where Abraham tried to sacrifice his son Issac because he heard(or thought he heard) a voice from the God. The Binding of Issac(video game), BoI for short, has a similiar story, but is set in a more modern setting.Issac(not that Issac from before) and his mother(name not revealed) lived in a small house. While Issac played with his toys, his mom watched Christian broadcasts from the TV. One day, his mom thought she heard a voice from the God, and he ordered her to kill Issac to prove her devotion. Issac, heard all of it and tried to escape. He found a trapdoor to his basement, and the game begins with him jumping down to it.McMillen wanted to show the positive yet the nagative affects of the game's developer Edmund McMillen had from the Scripture. McMillen makes a lot of dark humour and satire based games, and most of his creativity with the story of those games came from his Catholic mother and grandmother, and he thanks them for that. But his Christian dad was harsh on him, saying that playing games such as Magic: The Gathering and Dungeons & Dragons will lead him to hell.McMillen tried to tell this bible's positive effects and nagative effects on a child. It is very interesting, and it is even more so that even though 3 years have passed since the launch of this game, a solid explanation to the game's story hasn't been found yet. This was intended, as McMillen wanted this game to have many interpretations of it's endings, just like the Scripture.Now, to the gameplay aspects- it's a roguelike with some real-time aspect, combined with basic Legend of Zelda dungeon structure. The game has insane replay values, with over 100(or 200) items in the game, and 70(or more) of them is all stackable. You can trie out new combos with different enemies and bosses, such as combining a rapid fire laser weapon with a item that lets you charge, or combining a item which lowers your range but increases your damage with a weapon that inscreases your range.The game is lot like Zelda in this aspect where you don't know what things does until you try them out. The game also drops you bombs, keys, coins and health in various rooms, which is much like Zelda as well.The soundtrack is amazing, Danny Baranowsky did a fantastic job. It's one of those soundtracks that you would download to your phone or iTunes.This aspects makes this game really addicting, with you always telling to yourself "What will I get this time?". These games that makes you excited everytime you launch your game is a proof of a great game.The Binding of Issac definitely deserves an 8/10- it's a great game. I saw people saying this game is bad because it's too 'hard'. But that's the core mechanic of the game, you need to retry and see what happens next time. That's the general concept of a rogue-like. Some says that this game's only fun is it's item-combining aspects, but that's not true. If you look deeply into it's story as well, you will find it very interesting. The game's fun also comes from not only the Zelda aspects, but also from the rogue-like aspects.Unfortunately, The Binding of Issac is not a masterpiece(9/10). I want it to be, but I just feel like there's something missing here. Maybe it will be a masterpiece in The Binding of Issac: Rebirth, a remake to this game, which will not be made in 3 mouths. Yay.

Posted: June 19, 2015
												When there is a 2010's 'Indie Game Hall of Fame', The Binding of Issac will be one of its first inductees. Ed McMillen and Florian Himsl's top down rougelike dungeon crawler is a zebra in a field of wild horses. Its themes are what videogames and films try to avoid like the bubonic plague. In fact, I wouldn't be suprised if one of the bosses in this game has the bubonic plague (I'm looking at you, Gurdy). Infanticide, abortion, child abuse, and the idea that religion brainwashes would have some marketing departments cleaning out their desks. But this beautful departure isn't where The Binding of Issac shines. The gameplay is solid gold. The Legend of Zelda is a huge influence, and the game touts it well. Replayabilty is off the charts thanks to randomized levels, items, and boss fights. The pacing of difficulty and item unlocks as you progess feels reasonable. The soundtrack composed by Danny Baranowsky provides an added dimension into the hell that is Issac's basement, and its a damn good one. The community surrounding this game is extremely dedicated, constantly creating lore for a game that leaves a lot of blanks. The "Wrath of the Lamb DLC" (2012), and recently added "Eternal Edition" (2015) added substantial content to the game. Do yourself a favor and play this game until your eyes bleed (I hear toothpicks for your eyelids will help).

Posted: September 28, 2014
												I've played this game for about 100 or so hours, just not on steam. And if you don't own this, at the time of this review, you can get the base game and the DLC for $1. Or 100 pennies. 20 nickels. 4 quarters. You can't beat that. Pick it up.Anyways, actual review time.TONS of replayability. But be warned: if you're playing this game for the first time, it's hard. It does not hold your hand. The items that you pick up don't even have descriptions of what they do. But fear not! The Binding of Isaac wiki will be your new Bible (pun slightly intended, for those of you that have played Isaac) for about the first 50 runs or so. But about that difficulty....it's hard, yes. But the satisfaction you feel after killing Mom for the first time is probably the most accomplished I've felt pressing certain keys and watching things happen on a screen. Worth every penny.

												Oh Lord, where to start?This. Game. Oh my God. I'm almost speechless of how much i adore this game.The Binding of Isaac is a brilliant game from the amazing minds of Team Meat/Edmund McMillen (Super Meat Boy, Aether, Time ♥♥♥♥). I'm going to go on a record and say that I can't play the same game without stopping unless i absolutely worship it. This is one of the rare cases where I can play this game FOREVER. Just seriously please buy this game you will NOT regret it!

Posted: January 17, 2015
												Let me start this review by saying that I hated the game at the beginning so much that I wrote a negative review about it. I hated the bugs, the lags because of the poor (flash based) game engine and of course the ultra-hard difficulty. So why did I change my opinion about it? Well, I still kinda hate it but not in a bad way :)The Binding of Isaac is a game for hardcore gamers! Period. We all have been spoiled by the new(er) games with lengthy tutorials, huge amounts of hints and by a difficulty so easy that you're asking yourself if the game is made for kids. Not with this game! The difficulty is hard. Extremely hard! You need to have fast reflexes, think and move smart and if all else fails then only luck can save you. Even when you know all of the dirty tricks and moves of your enemies, there's still no guarantee you won't get hit and eventually die. It's always a challenge no matter how good you're at it and on top of that the randomly generated levels offer endless replay value.Long story short; this game will make you a better gamer overall. You don't believe me? Now hear me out. I just collected the final achievement called "Platinum God!" and the feeling is amazing. I feel like I can tackle and complete every game out there. It was worth every hour I spent with the game even though I was mad, frustrated, angry and in a rage quit mood quite often. Be warned though. You need a lot of patience, skills and balls of steel to beat this game. So if you're a casual gamer avoid it all cost.GG!

Posted: June 7, 2015
												I just realized, I haven't written a positive review for this game, even though it is my second most played game in my library!Even with the obviously superior Rebirth out now, the original Flash-Isaac is still a very compelling, yet rock hard experience. As far as flash games go, this is probably one of the very best - if not THE very best - positive example. Like many roguelites (is this the correct classification for purists?) it is brutally hard and unforgiving in the beginning, but the more you play it, the more you get the hang of it, the further you will get, until eventually, you can start a run and know "okay, I will most probably finish it after an hour, if the items I get aren't COMPLETELY garbage."Now, with the new "eternal edition" update out, it's worth revisiting the old times.I recommend buying the original, IF you are already through with Rebirth and:-Want to see, where Rebirth came from and how the original incarnation played differently-Want to listen to an, in my humble opinion, slightly better soundtrack - but that's highly subjective!Otherwise, if you haven't played any of Isaac at all yet, you might want to skip this and start with Rebirth instead, except if you want to relive the process of improvement.Recommended.

Posted: April 12, 2013
Cry or DieA former shell of a boy turned lump-of-flesh, Isaac must endure the horrors of lost siblings that never came to be. These undead fetuses are hellbent on destroying Isaac's very way of living and are very angry, that is to say, not only at him but at his mother even more so. Mom receives a godsend message from the Lord one day, asking her to prove her devotion and faith by sacrificing her son, Isaac. Who knows if his late brothers and sisters suffered the same fate, but one thing's for certain, Isaac isn't going to wait to find out!Overall, the top-down arcade style of The Binding of Isaac is great fun to be had. The levels are generated at random each time, and knowing this, makes for high replay value... from an indie game no doubt! Enemies are unique in appearance, there are various items with special capabliities, and plus, you take down your foes by crying a surge of tear drops! Poor Isaac... more fun for us then!

Posted: June 19, 2015
												When there is a 2010's 'Indie Game Hall of Fame', The Binding of Issac will be one of its first inductees. Ed McMillen and Florian Himsl's top down rougelike dungeon crawler is a zebra in a field of wild horses. Its themes are what videogames and films try to avoid like the bubonic plague. In fact, I wouldn't be suprised if one of the bosses in this game has the bubonic plague (I'm looking at you, Gurdy). Infanticide, abortion, child abuse, and the idea that religion brainwashes would have some marketing departments cleaning out their desks. But this beautful departure isn't where The Binding of Issac shines. The gameplay is solid gold. The Legend of Zelda is a huge influence, and the game touts it well. Replayabilty is off the charts thanks to randomized levels, items, and boss fights. The pacing of difficulty and item unlocks as you progess feels reasonable. The soundtrack composed by Danny Baranowsky provides an added dimension into the hell that is Issac's basement, and its a damn good one. The community surrounding this game is extremely dedicated, constantly creating lore for a game that leaves a lot of blanks. The "Wrath of the Lamb DLC" (2012), and recently added "Eternal Edition" (2015) added substantial content to the game. Do yourself a favor and play this game until your eyes bleed (I hear toothpicks for your eyelids will help).

												This game teaches you to wash your hands before food.Indeed, if you pay attention - you'll see that all your enemies are, in fact, hallucinations of your vivid unstable child's mind. They are grotesque versions of himself, trying to bully him.The reason for all this is quite simple: your hero (Isaac) doesn't like wearing clothes and touches a lot of dirty things: spoons, shoes, hourglass (very dirty), mom's panties, etc.Germs are transmitted very easily, and since you play as a child with a weak immune system, it's very likely that you've caught something because of your careless behaviour.You deserve to die.

Posted: August 14, 2014
												Binding of Isaac is that kind of game that has a relatively long learning curve but it´s fun is mostly hidden in mad combinations of items and passive abilities and almost total randomness. Even though Isaac has no theme in common with FTL, I found these two games briliant in their way of making you playing it again and again just because you might find something new, the game is never the same and the more you play the more you are actually able to enjoy it (maybe exploit it?).For me, I found 0 bugs or glithces , so gameplay is more than enjoyable on both fronts : fun from the game itself (plot, mechanisms, easter eggs and hidden references...) and the actual game programming (AI, smoothly running, no bugs...). I guess that at the start, I was a lot confused about all the items, trinkets and cards because it is really immersive when it comes to quantity, but few visits of wikia now and then makes it more clear as you pass more time playing it. Don´t let that make you stop playing this game! Those few stats, cards, pills and items with no self-explainitory describtions are really worth to learn because you will want to play it again and again and again...One big recommendation when it comes to this game : buy it! Play it! It´s crazy how addictive and good it is. And from what i heard th creators made it in only few months!

Posted: September 8, 2013
												The Binding of Isaac is an amazing game that mixes elements from The Legend of Zelda dungeon crawling all the way to games like Minecraft with it's randomization. In the Binding of Isaac, you play as a small boy called, Issac who is chased down into the basement of his house due to his Mother believing that she is hearing the voice of God.      You can collect many different types of Weapons in the Binding of Isaac. Ranging from arrows, to bombs, to stranger things such as ipecac, to brimstone, to chocolate milk! There more items than just weapons. You can collect things that will aid you on your journey such as dog food (Additional health), and Pyro (You grow fuses in your head that give you 99 bombs). There is a great diversity of items in the game and it is very unlikely that you will get the same items in next playthroughs.     Now, all of these items don't mean much if the combat is bad. And it is not. Rooms are randomly generated and there is quite a selection of enemies to fight. All the enemies in the game serve a specific role to play. There are not many different types of bosses however in the game, which does mean that you repeat a boss that you fought in a previous run.     All in all, the binding of isaac is a great dungeon crawling game and plenty of randomization to make each run different.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												"If there are two people who I believe are going to save hardcore gaming, it's Hideki Kamiya and Edmund McMillen."-SelfCreated behind the same mind that brought you Super Meat Boy, The Binding of Isaac is a randomly-generated dungeon crawler with light rpg elements present and constant action. Set in a twisted atmosphere with dark themes ranging from child abuse, gender identity, suicide, abortion and how religion might negatively affect a child, you play as Isaac; a child who is relentlessly being hunted by his mother, who believes her son is corrupted by sin and must sacrifice him to prove her love to her god after hearing his voice. The game can be brutal at moments, due to not knowing how the game is played and randomly generated levels. However, the longer you play the game, the better you will understand how the game is played and where secrets are placed, what the items do and attack patterns your enemies display. It instructs you with trial and error gameplay and it's random but understandable level design. This is easily one of the best designed games I've ever played, and look forward to the remake of this game.Since this is a flash game,however, expect to have random framerate crashes, as the game is packed with so much content there will be moments where the game will slow down and may even stop responding.If you are a fan of the NES Legend of Zelda dungeioneering and/or a challenging game with a test of wits and reflexes, this is for you.

Posted: August 8, 2014
												From the team behind Super meat boy comes this game. A Roguelike aka Survival Action Shooter game based on the Original Legend of Zelda 1 for the Nintendo Entertainment System.This game is deeply disturbing, featuring the life and experiences of an abused child of a mother who's a christian fundamentalist. Not only is this game a religion critique that will make your fedora spin, its also a deep delve into the mind and insanity à la being John Malkovich.The graphics are alright and characterful, simple drawings with a fat black outline, yet manage to make the hair on your neck stand up. Soundtrack delivered by the mastermind Danny Baranowsky. He offers a mishmash of techno, dubstep and chip music that will enhance the feeling of anxiety that you will get playing this. A weak point of this game is, that it gets repetitive. Once you threw yourself at this broad meat grinder of monsters and traps often enough and given that you get lucky with the items, you practically breeze though the floors all in the same fashion.Hopefully this will get mixed up with a future update. ALSO important is to mention that this game lacks a safe function.This definately needs to changeAlso that this game is required to run on flash is ridicoulous, making it hard to interact with steam, but not impossible.As it stands you get a great bargain of a game with inexpensive yet filling DLC, loads of collectibles, challenges, achievements and a statistic score. Its yours for 5,00 Euros.Prepare to meet a form of fear and disturbance you've never expected to be presented in this kind of formate.

Posted: August 4, 2014
												Binding of Issac is a small indie game from the offices of Newgrounds, and like every Newground game, its simple and sweet to keep your attention for your torrent of "The Dark Knight" to download.The game is a simple thriller, 3rd person static shooter around the character of Issac as he escapes his homicidal, Christian mother through a maze of dungeons. Using tears and demonic and unique items to kill his chlorinated genepool creations of his  (I guess) brothers. The game is small in size and relatively simple mechanics to grasp the game play easily. Plus the graphical style is so good it looked develpoted in the designers' Mother's basement. Overall it's a good game to play when you don't want to spend the time loading Fallout or a heavy game like L4D.

Posted: August 4, 2014
												I'm going to write down what I feel about this game because I'm not a professional reviewer of games...The Binding of Isaac is a gem withing the indie genre and you know it, I know it, hell...even your granny knows it. The game offers tons and tons of hours of play time. Through the randomly generated dungeons and over 100 items to help you kill many different types of enemies and difficult yes fun bosses. Yes the game has a learning curve, and not a easy one, but once you get in the hang of things in this game it really shows what its got. One of the best things about this game is the music, oh boy the sweet sounds of this game given to us by Mr. Baranowski are freaking unforgettable. Every level having its own theme and even bosses have their own music to get pumped to. BOI also features different characters to play as, each woth their strength and weaknesses. So to summarize here is a pro/con list!PROS:-Randomly generated levels-Over 100 items to master-Tons of different enemies and bosses to defeat-THE MUSIC IN THIS GAME IS GIVEN TO US BY THE GODS-Different characters to play and master, each with strenghts and weaknesses-Tons of different kinds of enemies CONS :(-Steep learning curve Yeah that's it for cons :)And don't even get me started on the DLC, Wrath of the Lamb, because it's a whole another experienceProdigy OUT
