Posted: February 5, 2014
												This game is one of the greatest games I have ever played. It sort of reminds me of old school Zelda dungeons mixed with Super Meat Boy (but that's just because it's the same creator which gives it the same art style). This game literally has an infinite replay value. It takes a little while to get used to it, and may require a lot of practice, but there is a MAJOR feeling of gratitude once you kill mom (you'll understand once you play it). And if you think it stops after that, you are painfully wrong. There is a DLC that EVERYONE should buy day one. It makes the game nearly impossible to beat...nearly. This game deserves all the praise it reseves. 10/10, definetly buy. Plus, it's like 5 bucks, that's practically nothing for an unlimited amount of fun!

Posted: December 15, 2014
												This is a magical game. Think original Legend of Zelda crossed with Risk of Rain and you're probably starting to get an idea. The wonder of discovering new items, the horror of unlocking new creepy music (!), the despair of watching Isaac's family fall apart at the final ending. It's all there. From Edmund McMillen's lovable, twisted art style to the game's deceptively simple and addictive mechanics, this game is one of the best I have ever seen. There really aren't any bad points about it. It takes a while to master, but boy is it worth it when you do. This is one of the few games where completing objectives actually feels rewarding. I have played this game for 2 years and still have 25% to go before I'm finished. At full price, you will get your money's worth and discover the true meaning of replayability.

Posted: April 5, 2012
												Take a cross between the original Legend of Zelda's dungeons, bullet hell games like R-Type, and rogue-like games and you've got The Binding of Isaac. The game is simple yet very fluid. It's chock full of grotesque humor (one of the power ups is a Wire Coat Hanger) and disturbing imagery. The difficulty varies room to room and can be pretty brutal. There is no saving, so you only have one life (unless you find a 1-UP or other item). Each time you play the game everything - bosses, items, rooms, everything - is random. For a measly five bucks, six with the sound track, it's totally worth buying. Plus, hey, not only is it made by the creators of Super Meat Boy it also has one helluva awesome soundtrack, too.

Posted: November 20, 2014
												Well, considering I recently logged my 100th hour, I figured I would write a review.What can I say about this game? Well...anyone who asks me, I tell them that it's the wierdest game you'll ever see. Perhaps that's not entirely true, but it's rather close.Isaac is a rouguelike that is probably the hardest game that I've ever played. It's incredably frustraiting to simply play it for fun, but thankfully the game has nice tiers of bosses to defeat, and some bosses are just simply rewarding to kill due to their difficulty.Anyone new to the game will die, and any veteran will die often as well. The game is unforgiving and, as I said, incredibly difficult. One aspect that I don't like is it's heavily RNG, but the game does kinda adress that once you've beat it a few times *cough10-15cough*I honestly don't know why I still play it. I think it's because the challenge itself allures me, and the fact that I have 100 hours there's still so much to do. The game has a few gates requiring you to beat it again in order to proceed, and that's what i like about it. If you don't like difficulty, anger, and death, don't buy this. But if you're willing to struggle through and recieve the great feeling of awesomeness when you succeed after 200 runs, then this is for you.

Posted: November 1, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac looks and feels like a flash game; something you could play for free online. It looks like someone had an idea, said "hey, wouldn't this be cool?" and made it.But if you can get past that, The Binding of Isaac is surprisingly thorough. It's a Roguelike - you die, you start again. You gather items and powerups in order to ramp up your character and clear the dungeon. And boy are there a lot of items; it wasn't until at the very least my fifth playthrough that I started to see repeats at all, and according to the wiki, there are dozens of things left to discover.That being said, there's no way to see what some of these items actually do before using them. The tarot cards which are usually one-time effects have consistent effects through all playthroughs, but there's so many of them it's hard to remember. There's multitudes of passive collectables you could potentially find which end up helping you create a 'build', and you never know what you'll get (or what they even do, if they require an activation).Despite finding multitudes of what I thought were "broken OP" items, the difficulty in this game is fairly high, and despite at least twenty attempts, I've only managed to beat the game once. And like any Roguelike game, exploration, while rewarding, is extremely dangerous! Unlike a game such as FTL where you are encouraged to finish every encounter you can in order to build up enough power, Isaac's hard limit on healing items forces players to rethink trying to explore the entire dungeon, and for once, NOT exploring can sometimes be the tactical choice.The game produces mountains of tough little choices. Do you permanently lower your health for a good item? Which active ability is best to keep, since you can only have one? Do you go through the spiked door where you will take guaranteed damage for a shot at loot? Do you use your key on the chest in front of you, or is there a shop down the road that can help you unload cash?Unfortunately, these decisions are sometimes uninformed. Again, without a way to see what an item does before picking it up, experimentation is required. This can be painful when you are asked to pay a health container or two before even figuring out what it does, or you activate something that teleports you, or some other unexpected event.If you can handle the sort of gross nature of the environment, this is a Roguelike which'll keep you busy for a few hours.

Posted: March 20, 2015
												I think this is the sort of game that grows on you with time.Initially I found this game very challenging to the point that I was very close to giving up. But, if you're persistent with this game you'll get better, to the point at which completing the game 9 times over (for the achievements) is do-able.It's worth mentioning though that the first completion gives you a false sense of victory. If you dare to play it again you'll realise that it goes to a whole new level of difficulty (2 more levels to be precise). Everything will start damaging you double and the game has suddenly gone hardcore. But as I say, if you're persistent you will get good at this game and you'll find it enjoyable - especially if you're the achievement-hunting type.So, to summarise I'd recommend this game as a self-purchase or a gift for more experienced gamers with at least a few years under their belt. It's definitely not for the faint-hearted though, or those less experienced (i.e. casual or intermediate gamers) simply because this is a difficult game, and they might be a bit quick to give up the game forever.

Posted: July 10, 2014
												The Binding of Issac is a fun dungeon crawler that brings the rogue-like genre back to it's roots. The Binding of Issac understands how pacing works and that players need to spend most of the game gearing up for the final boss battle. It mixes a memerable soundtrack with an intriguing art style to create a difficult yet nostalgic game that will keep you playing for hours. While I am on the subject of The Binding of Issac, the DLC, Wrath of The Lamb, adds TONS more content for the mere price of £1.99. This is how I believe expansion packs should be handled rather than the current expectation of "a couple more skins". I would reccomend this game to gamers who enjoy dungeon crawlers, intense soundtracks and a beautiful aethstetics style.

Posted: December 18, 2014
												A classic up there with the likes of Super Mario Bros. and Legend of Zelda (who it pays homage to). THE rogue-like of all rogue-likes and one of only four 10/10 games I have ever experienced (another of which is Binding of Isaac: Rebirth). If you haven't played this game yet, you owe it to yourself to give it a try. For the hours upon hours of replay value that you'll get from this game, you CAN NOT beat the price. Seriously. I have put in an easy 120 hours into this one alone not counting the other 100 hours I have invested in Rebirth so far (and I've just barely scratched the surface on that one).The game seems so simple the first time you play it. And then you play it again and realize it's like playing an entirely different game. And so on, and so on. There are just so many builds, unlockables and other variables, no 2 runs ever feel exactly the same. One of, if not THE most replayable game I've ever played.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												This game is really addictive and really hard. I would recommend keeping its wikia open when you play it. If you are looking for a serious challenge then buy this game and its one DLC. Remeber, the more you play the harder it gets.You might be thinking "Doesn't every game do that?" Well yes at least for the most part. THIS GAME DOES IT DIFFERENTLY! With every boss you beat for the first time, a enemy type of enemy spawns on your current and later attempts.This means that the more you fail, the harder it gets. You'll find yourself checking the wikia on every item you find and sometimes what may sound really good turns out to be really bad.If you really want to trust your luck, rage, or challenge yourself, buy this game.

												It's not quite Dungeons of Dredmor--which is by far the better deal--but it is fun in its own right, mixing the most shallow the roguelike experience can offer with the most shallow of Zelda dungeon-crawling.  It works darn well as a pick-up-and-play title, with you either victorious (unlikely) or dead all under 20 minutes.  However far you get is largely determined by the luck of the randomly-generated draw: power-ups you get, health available, enemies you face.The perfect title if ye're lookin' for a time-killer.  You'll probably never see all the collectables and secrets the game has to offer.

Posted: October 3, 2014
												Isaac and his mother lived alone in a small house on a hill. Isaac kept to himself drawing pictures and playing with his toys as his mom watched Christian broadcasts on the television. Life was simple and they were both happy. That was until the day Isaac's mom heard a voice from above:"Your son has become corrupted by sin. He needs to be saved.""I will do my best to save him, my Lord," Isaac's mother replied, rushing into Isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life.Again the voice called to her:"Isaac's soul is still corrupt. He needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world and confess his sins.""I will follow your instructions, Lord. I have faith in thee," Isaac's mother replied as she locked Isaac in his room away from the evils of the world.One last time Isaac's mom heard the voice of God calling to her:"You've done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to me. To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you.""Yes, Lord. Anything," Isaac's mother begged."To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice. Your son, Isaac, will be this sacrifice. Go into his room and end his life as an offering to me, to prove you love me above all else.""Yes, Lord," she replied, grabbing a butchers knife from the kitchen.Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear. Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trapdoor to the basement hidden under his rug. Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch just as his mother burst through his door and threw himself down into the unknown depths below...

Posted: May 3, 2012
												It plays like a shmup but feels like the original Legend of Zelda in many ways (from level design to music and items). Everything is randomly generated. Everything from the treasures within each dungeon to the bosses you face at the end. Sometimes you'll get a really awesome item like the Book of Relevations or a Dinner, and sometimes you might just find Mr. Boom! or The Belt. Sometimes you might face Monstro or sometimes you might have to deal with War or Famine. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for a game with high replayability. The music is great, the gameplay is simple yet addictive, and I'm always trying to find new  treasures and beat that next boss.So, are you ready to hear Isaac's story?

Posted: September 8, 2013
												The Binding of Isaac is an amazing game that mixes elements from The Legend of Zelda dungeon crawling all the way to games like Minecraft with it's randomization. In the Binding of Isaac, you play as a small boy called, Issac who is chased down into the basement of his house due to his Mother believing that she is hearing the voice of God.      You can collect many different types of Weapons in the Binding of Isaac. Ranging from arrows, to bombs, to stranger things such as ipecac, to brimstone, to chocolate milk! There more items than just weapons. You can collect things that will aid you on your journey such as dog food (Additional health), and Pyro (You grow fuses in your head that give you 99 bombs). There is a great diversity of items in the game and it is very unlikely that you will get the same items in next playthroughs.     Now, all of these items don't mean much if the combat is bad. And it is not. Rooms are randomly generated and there is quite a selection of enemies to fight. All the enemies in the game serve a specific role to play. There are not many different types of bosses however in the game, which does mean that you repeat a boss that you fought in a previous run.     All in all, the binding of isaac is a great dungeon crawling game and plenty of randomization to make each run different.

Posted: February 6, 2015
												I guess I'm late to the party, but that this game is more than recommended can't be stressed enough.The Binding of Isaac is a roguelike with almost unlimited replay value, lots of black humor and a story skillfully told with just a hand full of spoken words.Playing through the game multiple times unlocks new items, levels and difficulties and the ride does not seem to ever stop. Other than many roguelike games, it manages to never get unfair - the player always has strategies at hand that can get him through the game. It may take him some (or some more) tries in the beginning tho :)Add this up with a lovely soundtrack and a DLC that doubles the already vast content and you've got a month, a quarter, maybe even half a year covered.There's just one downside: The Binding of Isaac Rebirth is now out - a remake improving on almost every aspect whilst also adding massive content. You may consider getting this one instead.

Posted: November 23, 2013
												Bindin of Issac is a true gem, it's artwork sets a strange tone, the monsters are -as i said- monsters that make you panick extremely when you have low hp, and the powerups are vast and all unique. The monsters are simply no pushover, each one has to potiental to kill you, and therefore a gamer has to think about strategies to defeat them. Also there are plenty of secrets thrown around for the player to discover and defeat (Bosses). And the Biblic references strewn about add another, calming and sometimes sinister, tone. 												So far, this game has given me the most replayability value of all time. The maps and monsters are all randomly generated in each play, so even though the experience is similar each time, it is always a bit different on each play. The myriad of achievements allows for countless goals for those who like to complete tasks, and it is always fun to see what kinds of monsters and item combinations you can work with next for those who enjoy seeing the possibilities of a game.The graphics are dorky, gross, and simplistic, but I think that is part of the appeal for a McMillen game. Also, though the story with Isaac and his Mother is not exactly the most emphatic or traditionally presented part of the game, or what really keeps a person playing it (I imagine), it definitely adds a boost in character to the game and really opens a lot to think on if one decides they feel like doing so.TLDR; play it. Its pretty awesome.

Posted: July 14, 2014
												Isaac comes to in the upper level of the basement and you, the player, must guide him through the dangers that lurk below. The UI is very similar to what you’d expect from an early Zelda title. You have three heart containers. Three counters keep track of your amount of coins, bombs, and keys. The dungeon layout is shown on the upper left and your current items are listed next to your heart containers. You start out with only your tears to fight off the grotesque creatures of the basement. Each floor of the basement is littered with a slew of enemies, chests, items, a treasure room, and a boss room. Upon entering a room, all of the doors will lock until every enemy in it has been defeated. You can blow open a door, but it will cost a single bomb. Useable items can often be found in chests, but are also dropped from enemies. These could be tarot cards, pills, or some other miscellaneous item. Where as the tarot cards have a specific use, pills have random uses. These range from incredibly useful to potentially harmful, so consume them at your own risk. Treasure rooms are marked by their gold outlines, and within them lies a single power-up. These power-ups can increase your speed, change your projectile type, increase your max HP, etc. Some power-ups are weak and their effects can leave more to be desired, while others can be complete game changers and turn the tide of battles in your favor. They’re creatively designed and include some pretty outlandish things like a pair of high heels and even dog food. They also change your physical appearance, and seeing as they stack infinitely, this can result in some pretty hilarious or gruesome appearances. As you progress throughout the game, Isaac’s exterior begins to reflect the hell that is the basement. There are a plethora of bosses and they all battle in different ways. Defeating a boss will open a trapdoor to the next level, and between each floor of the basement a cutscene plays that shows Isaac having a nightmare, often of him being publicly embarrassed. The cutscenes, although oddly humorous, add little depth to Isaac’s character as it can be assumed that the events he worries over never actually took place, seeing as some are pretty over-the-top, such as one where he dreams he was being pooped on by a group of people. The final boss is no other than Isaac’s mother. And even after you’ve managed to beat her, your adventure still isn’t over. There still remains another set of levels and a whole mess of enemies, secrets, items, and power-ups to find.Through and through, The Binding of Isaac is a bonafide roguelike in every sense of the term. Every dungeon is randomly generated, resulting in no two runs feeling exactly the same. You’re given simple controls and absolutely no tutorial of any sort. Like any self-respecting roguelike, this is a game of trial and error, and it isn’t afraid to hand you your behind on a silver platter. The staggering amount of enemies will force you to adapt to any situation, and you’ll find yourself dying often before you’ve learned most of the enemies’ maneuvers. Bosses deal a lot of damage fast and some will even spawn smaller enemies around themselves. Even after you’ve learned the behavior of every enemy in the game, you’ll still find yourself dying quite often. Useable items and power-ups add variation to the gameplay and the tactics you’ll use in combat. With the unbelievable amount of depth found in the seemingly simple game, The Binding of Isaac produces an experience that becomes insanely addictive and rarely feels stale, even after dozens of hours of playtime.The Binding of Isaac’s visual presentation is something straight from the mind of a madman. Its art style is sleek, simple, and endearing. The various brown hues of the basement stand apart from each other, enhanced by the excellent shading, but they’re just pieces in a whole that create an immersive and beautiful environment. The story is primarily told through Isaac’s drawings. It’s all nice and cutesy, that is until you actually walk around and see the dreadful conditions of the basement. A myriad of deformed and bloody enemies stalk the rooms and each seem to spout blood like a fountain upon dying. There are these worm-like enemies that actually look somewhat adorable, until they charge at you with their fangs bared, trying to eat your face off. Piles of poop lay scattered on the ground. The changes that accompany the power-ups can be humorous, but others completely change the way Isaac looks, essentially turning him into one of the monsters that he faces. The fact that you aren’t alone suggests that you aren’t the first to face the wickedness of Isaac’s mother, and the possibility that the enemies could be related to him makes the adventure even more cringe worthy. In some dungeons you’ll find a room in which you can purchase items in exchange for coins. Each of these shops feature a hanging Isaac-lookalike, their faces twisted with expressions of despair. It’s an enthralling visual endeavor that shocks you from the start and carries out its dark themes with precise execution.The Binding of Isaac’s soundtrack aims to emphasize the same contrast brought about by the art style, and it manages to do so quite well. The music is slightly upbeat and detracts from the hopelessness that Isaac feels as he wanders through the basement. At times the music speeds up just a bit and the volume increases, ramping up your adrenaline at the same time. There is a slight feeling of loneliness in the unknown created by the soundtrack, and this is where it slightly fractures the contrast and actually melds with the setting. Enemy and projectile sounds are squishy in nature, but impactful overall. The contrast between the game’s dark themes and relatively uplifting music is genuinely interesting and adds another layer of depth.Despite its numerous references and tie-ins to other forms of media, The Binding of Isaac does plenty to set itself apart from the pack. There are some really laughable moments in the otherwise grim depths of the basement: there’s a certain enemy that will scurry away from you, whimpering as it tries desperately to flee; of the hanging Isaac-lookalikes in the shops, one of them has a huge grin on his face; some of the items and power-ups are just meant to make you burst out laughing, like Mom’s Pad – a useable item that makes all enemies in a room retreat for several seconds. Also, it raises some very serious questions that most games wouldn’t dare ask. It ventures into often-untraveled territory by challenging our understanding of organized religion, mental illness, and child abuse. These are very touchy subjects and it’s admirable to see developers who aren’t afraid to speak on them. The Binding of Isaac proves to be a unique and addictive adventure. Its humor is welcoming and its roguelike nature results in an unbelievable amount of replay value. While it may look simple at first, there is a surprising amount of depth to be found. Its endearing art style and aesthetically pleasing soundtrack is welcoming, while its dark themes are perfectly executed in the story and character designs. More than just a fun game, it questions what we as a society perceive to be norms and challenges us to think differently. The only real downsides to the game are the lack of characterization on Isaac and the slight capitalization on nostalgia. Aside from that, it’s an incredible game that should be played by anyone who enjoys a solid roguelike – or just a good game in general – because it stands head and shoulders above its competition in the genre.

Posted: January 21, 2014
												I've played 300+ hours of The Binding of Isaac. If anyone's qualified to talk about this game, it's people like me. I love this game so much that I bought the $40.00 on-disc copy. Now, without further ado, let's get down to brass tacks. TBoI is a randomly-generated "rougue-like" heavily inspired by games such as The Legend of Zelda, which happens to be one my all time favorite franchises. The items you acquire on each new and different run alter both your playstyle and your appearance, forcing you to adapt to new strategies and find new ways to overcome your foes. All of these elements combine to create one of the most complete packages I've ever seen in a game. Tack on a DLC that doubles the content and a remake on the horizen, and you've got the best game $5.00 (or $1.24) can buy.

Posted: November 9, 2014
												It might look simple at first sight, but believe me, The Binding of Isaac is one of the deepest roguelikes out there, without being too complex. It might look cute at first sight, but don't be fooled, this biblical inspired game is disgusting and will throw lots of gore and poop at you. All this in a randomly generated world filled with secrets and hundreds of items. It's like playing an entire new game each time. It will challenge you, surprise you, attach you, and entertain you for hours, days, months, years. An instant classic and one of my favourite games of all time. I still recommend this while Rebirth (the remastered edition) is out, because it still has charm, having a separate soundtrack and different visual style. It's the one that started it all.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												  Binding of Isaac is a game that gives a ton for the price it's offered at. I have spent 226 hours on the game (Wrath of the Lamb included) and still from time to time play it. The game is difficult and has randomized elements in it, so some playtroughs you might just get bad items and die quickly, but usually it's still your fault. When playing it also is "mysterious" with what the items given do with short and sometimes cryptic descriptions, so you can try to learn them by playing or look up from a wiki (wich is what I did).  The story of the game is not really anything great (as it is not the main focus of the game) but it sets the mood and does add to the game in a way.  The music ( composed by Danny Baranowsky) in Binding of Isaac is quite odd, but fits the game in question very well and isn't bad on its own either.  The game is clearly not for everyone and if wanted to be compleated, it takes a long time as you'll be dying so often. I, personally still liked the game very much and will still keep playing it from time to time. I recommend the game wholeheartedly to anyone interested in it, especially for its cheap price.

												At 5 dollars, The Binding of Issac is one of those little gems that pays for itself within a few minutes.From start to finish it's only about 20 - 25 min in length.Of course that's when you manage to not die over and over and over.After you manage to beat the game the first time, is when Isaac really begins to shine.I personally like a challenging games, but when it takes you two or more hours to beat the game for the first time,considering how small it is, and after dying more times than I can count, it really makes it frustrating, and difficult to buckle down and start from scratch time after time.However, after you do manage to beat it, the feeling of overwhelming accomplishment is more than enough to convince me to keep playing.Another detracting feature is the redundancy of the soundtrack. 												Binding of Isaac is that kind of game that has a relatively long learning curve but it´s fun is mostly hidden in mad combinations of items and passive abilities and almost total randomness. Even though Isaac has no theme in common with FTL, I found these two games briliant in their way of making you playing it again and again just because you might find something new, the game is never the same and the more you play the more you are actually able to enjoy it (maybe exploit it?).For me, I found 0 bugs or glithces , so gameplay is more than enjoyable on both fronts : fun from the game itself (plot, mechanisms, easter eggs and hidden references...) and the actual game programming (AI, smoothly running, no bugs...). I guess that at the start, I was a lot confused about all the items, trinkets and cards because it is really immersive when it comes to quantity, but few visits of wikia now and then makes it more clear as you pass more time playing it. Don´t let that make you stop playing this game! Those few stats, cards, pills and items with no self-explainitory describtions are really worth to learn because you will want to play it again and again and again...One big recommendation when it comes to this game : buy it! Posted: June 7, 2015
												I just realized, I haven't written a positive review for this game, even though it is my second most played game in my library!Even with the obviously superior Rebirth out now, the original Flash-Isaac is still a very compelling, yet rock hard experience. As far as flash games go, this is probably one of the very best - if not THE very best - positive example. Like many roguelites (is this the correct classification for purists?) it is brutally hard and unforgiving in the beginning, but the more you play it, the more you get the hang of it, the further you will get, until eventually, you can start a run and know "okay, I will most probably finish it after an hour, if the items I get aren't COMPLETELY garbage."Now, with the new "eternal edition" update out, it's worth revisiting the old times.I recommend buying the original, IF you are already through with Rebirth and:-Want to see, where Rebirth came from and how the original incarnation played differently-Want to listen to an, in my humble opinion, slightly better soundtrack - but that's highly subjective!Otherwise, if you haven't played any of Isaac at all yet, you might want to skip this and start with Rebirth instead, except if you want to relive the process of improvement.Recommended.

Posted: March 12, 2015
												This game is truly amazing. It's jsut so damn fun. I bought the Binding of Isaac Collection for less than $0.75, I expected it to be decent but it really is awesome. If I would have known how fun this game was, i would have even paid full price for it; definetly worth it.*Pros:- Tons of Bosses- They even added mini-bosses!- Tons of items and many categories (Trinkets, cards, pills, etc) - Different types of rooms, chest, and more- This game actually presents gradual difficulty, each room gets harder- The rooms are generated, so each play through is never the same- Cheap!- The DLC actually changes gameplay whilst keeping the best aspects*Cons:- During the first couple of levels, I often encounter the same bosses (Pin, Duke of flies, etc) then I start seeing variety- When you pick up a pill, it gives the player of getting a good or bad item and is very rage inducing- If you die towards the end near the final levels, it causing lots of rage- Doesnt show the current stat changes, so the player has to remember the stats, and gets tougher to remember towards the later levels15/10 Stewie Simulator 2011-2015

												Binding of Isaac22 After these events, God tested Abraham and said to him, “Abraham!”Abraham answered, “I’m here.”2 God said, “Take your son, your only son whom you love, Isaac, and go to the land of Moriah. Offer him up as an entirely burned offering there on one of the mountains that I will show you.” 3 Abraham got up early in the morning, harnessed his donkey, and took two of his young men with him, together with his son Isaac. He split the wood for the entirely burned offering, set out, and went to the place God had described to him.4 On the third day, Abraham looked up and saw the place at a distance. 5 Abraham said to his servants, “Stay here with the donkey. The boy and I will walk up there, worship, and then come back to you.”6 Abraham took the wood for the entirely burned offering and laid it on his son Isaac. He took the fire and the knife in his hand, and the two of them walked on together. 7 Isaac said to his father Abraham, “My father?”Abraham said, “I’m here, my son.”Isaac said, “Here is the fire and the wood, but where is the lamb for the entirely burned offering?”8 Abraham said, “The lamb for the entirely burned offering? God will see to it,[a] my son.” The two of them walked on together.9 They arrived at the place God had described to him. Abraham built an altar there and arranged the wood on it. He tied up his son Isaac and laid him on the altar on top of the wood. 10 Then Abraham stretched out his hand and took the knife to kill his son as a sacrifice. 11 But the Lord’s messenger called out to Abraham from heaven, “Abraham? Abraham?”Abraham said, “I’m here.”12 The messenger said, “Don’t stretch out your hand against the young man, and don’t do anything to him. I now know that you revere God and didn’t hold back your son, your only son, from me.” 13 Abraham looked up and saw a single ram caught by its horns in the dense underbrush. Abraham went over, took the ram, and offered it as an entirely burned offering instead of his son. 14 Abraham named that place “the Lord sees.”[c] That is the reason people today say, “On this mountain the Lord is seen.”[d]15 The Lord’s messenger called out to Abraham from heaven a second time 16 and said, “I give my word as the Lord that because you did this and didn’t hold back your son, your only son, 17 I will bless you richly and I will give you countless descendants, as many as the stars in the sky and as the grains of sand on the seashore. They will conquer their enemies’ cities. 18 All the nations of the earth will be blessed because of your descendants, because you obeyed me.” 19 After Abraham returned to the young men, they got up and went to Beer-sheba where Abraham lived.☺/☃

												Oh Lord, where to start?This. Game. Oh my God. I'm almost speechless of how much i adore this game.The Binding of Isaac is a brilliant game from the amazing minds of Team Meat/Edmund McMillen (Super Meat Boy, Aether, Time ♥♥♥♥). I'm going to go on a record and say that I can't play the same game without stopping unless i absolutely worship it. This is one of the rare cases where I can play this game FOREVER. It's confusing, makes you think, it's funny, its gross, it's crazy, and downright addicting! Also, it's one of my favorite type of games, being a fan of randomly generated rogue-likes. I would also extremely highly reccomend getting the DLC, Wrath of the Lamb, as it is probably one of the largest and best DLCs I have ever seen. It's like if you grabbed a cake and smashed 10 more onto it and it made a perfect 11-layer cake. That's what this game is when you have the DLC, a perfected 11-layer cake! Just seriously please buy this game you will NOT regret it!

Posted: October 2, 2011
												"So if I die I start over?""yes. you start over with nothing.""You star over with knowledge."Binding o' Isaac is an action-arcade game, or 2D Zelda games mashed with random elements and perma-death. Crawling through your dungeon basement, you fight minion and boss abominations with your tears, while collecting stuff. You know, classic kid adventures.You will not win on your first game. The controls are odd and frustrating at first, but can be learned. And half the fun is doing it again, applying what you learned and having it pay off (and getting different loot!) Fighting itself is as fun as LttP (read: it gets the job done.)And everything is tongue-in-cheek dark. Made by half of Meat Boy's team, Ed says the story was based off some old christian VHS tapes he found. And upgrades are things like Isaac's puppy's head, which brings back the trauma and causes more tears.$5 (or $6, and get the ost, which is great.) Tons to unlock (characters, new items appear, cutscenes), Bible lore spin, and pretty fun. Check it.

Posted: January 5, 2014
												I'm not a fan of horror, I also get nauseous easy and panic easily. Binding of Isaac since it's debut was a game I mentally boxed as something other people with stronger mental fortitude play. It's creepy and disturbing, with a disarming art style and hearing the story second hand (And knowing the roots of Abraham and Isaac) did intrigue me but also made me uneasy. The Winter steam sale gave little more incentive for at least buying it, but I wouldn't recommending waiting for another sale, this game is immensely fun.There's a few games that walk, and talk like a horror like Gregory Horror Show and their ilk, which did put me off initially easily became a cult-classic, and this outclasses 'bubblegum goth' genre for quirky horror games. The game has little in way of a tutorial, and even less explanation of what every item does, but part of it's charm is exploration in a dark basement of the unknown and working things out for better or worse. Each run and level is randomly generated to keep you on your toes, there's various items that will help deal with the hideous enemies of Isaac's long-begotten and far less loved (or Lovely) siblings, of which they are legion and twisted in their variations. The game also while simple to grasp, does involve a deal of strategy later on; particularly when you find you can make a deal with the Devil for items that could turn the tide of your misfortune. Other more common rooms make such promises, that you'll need to crawl through a spiked door way to get to. Some items affect your primary weapon, which is a gag in itself, that you fight through the waves with your own tears. Give the game a simple test run, and you'll understand why this has unlimited ammo. The items also affect Isaac visually, and accumulating into making him just as horrifying as the abyss around him, and to be helpful: Even if you look like a Demon's Spermatozoa decked in black membrane with long, sharp gnashy teeth touching enemies will still kill you. I still have no idea why I thought I could eat them, .. but apparently this form gives me flight to get over ledges.Still Enjoy.
